thread.title: Mets know their World Series rotation and don't care if it's Kansas City Royals or Toronto Blue Jays
thread.title_full: Mets know their World Series rotation and don't care if it's Kansas City Royals or Toronto Blue Jays

author: Mike Vorkunov | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Mets know their World Series rotation and don't care if it's Kansas City Royals or Toronto Blue Jays
text:
Star Gazette comments Mets know their World Series rotation and don't care if it's Kansas City Royals or Toronto Blue Jays Comments 
NEW YORK â€” The Mets know their rotation for the World Series and it seems that they're just weighing whether to start Jacob deGrom or Matt Harvey for Game 1. The opponent, whether it's the Blue Jays or Royals, won't matter. 
Harvey was slated to pitch Game 5 of the National League Championship Series but there wasn't a need for one. Asked if extra rest will benefit him now, manager Terry Collins cryptically said "He's not going to get a lot of extra rest." 
Collins could also see a possibility of Harvey pitching three times in the World Series, which would likely mean as the Game 1 starter. 
DeGrom is the other option but Collins saw signs of fatigue in the starter during his outings lately. DeGrom struggled in, but won, his last two starts, which would make the manager cautious about putting the pitcher in a position to pitch three times in the World Series. RELATED: Unraveling the mystery of Marlins Man: The fan who is everywhere 
"The one thing we're looking at Jake is the last couple of times out he looked like he could use some time," Collins said. "He's been erratic with his command, and that to me is due to a little bit of fatigue, so it could be anybody. Is it going to benefit us to start him and use him three times? You've got to put them in situations where they're going to have more success. I'm not sure where we're going to go just yet. I like our rotation, no matter who's out there." 
If Harvey and deGrom start Games 1 and 2, which would be in Toronto or Kansas City, then Noah Syndergaard would start Game 3 and Steven Matz in Game 4. 
Collins doesn't want to announce the rotation until the Mets know their World Series opponent. He said an ESPN report that came out Friday morning was erroneous because the team had just decided on the order. 
"There can't be a report," Collins said. "We just had a meeting five minutes ago and I'm the only guy who's got the sucker written down."
